ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Focussed on speaking rather than semantic writing
I was able to develop my vocab and become more fluent as a result of the immersive teaching.
Largely the Spanish language, culture, and issues of Spanish-speaking areasart history, fables, and environmentalism.
I learned a lot about various important themes such as misogyny, fake news, and the importance of preserving indigenous culture.
Lots of practice with speaking Spanish fluidly and I became a lot more comfortable speaking the language

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Not too bad a workload despite being every day (this could depend on prof). Not too focussed on semantics and grammar - more about prof knowing what you are trying to say 
Weaknesses: Feel brainwashed into a liberal agenda to get a good grade

The greatest weakness is the computer use policy. Classes like this one thrive off student discussion in class, but the class is generally on their computers even when they are not needed, and as a result it is difficult for the prof to engage the students.

Strengths: the content felt very interesting and relevant and I enjoyed all the units. Weaknesses: it felt like we moved through a lot quickly yet superficially and I would have personally preferred a few less topics and the opportunity to delve deeper.
One of the strengths of this course was the projects we worked on during the asynchronous days. One of the weaknesses of this course was the play we read (I found it very confusing).
tough and challenging, witches section was pointless and unhelpful, not relevant and difficult to understand but rest was interesting

Strengths: I liked how we were encouraged to speak without too much focus on grammar and correctness. I was able to improve my fluidity speaking since I did not have to focus as much on speaking correctly.
Weaknesses: This class had a lot of work that was unequally distributed. Sometimes projects or large assignments would be assigned so they had to be done in one or two weekdays and then multiple days/weekends would be left with little to no work. For instance, a paper was assigned Monday, a full draft was due Wednesday, then we were given a full week to edit that paper before it was actually due. A more equal distribution would have helped make the workload more manageable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's a L4 language credit - take it if you have to / like languages
Probably not - its a pretty straightforward Spanish class that I wouldnt go out of my way to take.

From the perspective of a language requirement, I would. It was much more interesting and engaging than I was expecting, and although having class everyday resulted in more work than I was expecting, it ultimately felt manageable.
Yes, this course was a phenomenal way to build on my Spanish speaking abilities.
Yes, this is a good course to gain more Spanish skills and fulfill a language requirement.
